The number of steps required for convergence decreases.

questions.question_text_1:
A knn algorithm with k = 10 gives low training error and high validation error. What value of k
should we choose to get the better performance of the algorithm?
question_texts:
A knn algorithm with k = 10 gives low training error and high validation error. What value of k
should we choose to get the better performance of the algorithm?

options.option_text: Less than 10
Greater than 10

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following are multi label problems? For each option, assume suitable features are available.
question_texts: Which of the following are multi label problems? For each option, assume suitable features are available.

options.option_text: Predicted number of runs the Indian Cricket team will score in their next ODI.
Amount of money that Amitabh Bachchan’s next three movies each will make.
Predicting number of goals Ronaldo will score in next 10 matches each.
Predicting blood group of a person.
Predicting blood sugar level of a person for next 15 days each.

questions.question_text_1: In a random forest model let p < m be the number of randomly selected features that are used to identify the best split at any node of a tree. Which of the following are true? (m is the original number of features)
question_texts: In a random forest model let p < m be the number of randomly selected features that are used to identify the best split at any node of a tree. Which of the following are true? (m is the original number of features)

options.option_text: Increasing p reduces the correlation between any two trees in the forest.
Decreasing p reduces the correlation between any two trees in the forest.
Increasing p increases the performance of individual trees in the forest.
Decreasing p increases the performance of individual trees in the forest.

questions.question_text_1: Consider a neural network for a multi-class, image classification problem. When the network is trained on the images as they are, it does a good job on the test data. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D1 and the network N1. Assume that we now turn all images upside down, in both the training and test dataset. Now, the network with the same architecture is trained from scratch on this modified dataset. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D2 and network N2. Select the most appropriate option.
question_texts: Consider a neural network for a multi-class, image classification problem. When the network is trained on the images as they are, it does a good job on the test data. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D1 and the network N1. Assume that we now turn all images upside down, in both the training and test dataset. Now, the network with the same architecture is trained from scratch on this modified dataset. Call the dataset (train + test) for this setup D2 and network N2. Select the most appropriate option.

options.option_text: The network N2 will not be able to learn anything from D2. Its test accuracy onD2 will be very low.
The network N2 will be able to learn useful patterns from D2. In fact, theperformance of network N2 on D2 will be similar to N1 on D1.
The network N2 will be able to learn somewhat useful patterns from D2. Butthe performance of N1 on D1 will be much better than N2 on D2.

questions.question_text_1:
Two classifiers are trained on a dataset for a binary classification problem. They are then tested on the same dataset. The F1 scores of both classifiers are the same. (p1, r1) and (p2, r2) are the precision-recall scores for the two classifiers.  Consider the following statements:  Statement-1
If p1 > p2, then r1 < r2
Statement-2
If p1 = p2, then r1 = r2
Select the most appropriate option.
question_texts:
Two classifiers are trained on a dataset for a binary classification problem. They are then tested on the same dataset. The F1 scores of both classifiers are the same. (p1, r1) and (p2, r2) are the precision-recall scores for the two classifiers.  Consider the following statements:  Statement-1
If p1 > p2, then r1 < r2
Statement-2
If p1 = p2, then r1 = r2
Select the most appropriate option.

options.option_text: Statement-1 is correct, statement-2 is incorrect
Statement-1 is incorrect, statement-2 is correct
Both statements 1 & 2 are correct
Both statements 1 & 2 are incorrect

questions.question_text_1: Which of the following code blocks will produce the same value for the variable ‘Ans’? Assume the ‘numpy’ library is imported as ‘np’.
question_texts: Which of the following code blocks will produce the same value for the variable ‘Ans’? Assume the ‘numpy’ library is imported as ‘np’.

questions.question_text_1:
Rajesh trained a model on house price prediction problem. After training he came up with following model:   y = 4000 − 20 · x1 + 1500 · x2 − 15 · x3 + 3 · x4
 where, y is predicted house price, x1 is age of the house in years, x2 is the area of house/apartment in square feet, x3 is the number of floors the house/building is, x4 represents if the house is facing the sea or not.  According to Rajesh’s model, which of the following statements are correct?
question_texts:
Rajesh trained a model on house price prediction problem. After training he came up with following model:   y = 4000 − 20 · x1 + 1500 · x2 − 15 · x3 + 3 · x4
 where, y is predicted house price, x1 is age of the house in years, x2 is the area of house/apartment in square feet, x3 is the number of floors the house/building is, x4 represents if the house is facing the sea or not.  According to Rajesh’s model, which of the following statements are correct?

options.option_text: The most important factor in determining the price of the house is if it is seafacing or not.
No. of floors in the building is the most important feature.
Carpet area is the most important feature.
Age is the most important feature.
Age is the second most important feature.
None of these.
The polynomial regression model of degree 5 adds a smooth fitting to thisdata.
The polynomial regression model of degree 99 overfits this data.
The polynomial regression model of degree 1 adds a smooth fitting to thisdata.
The polynomial regression model of degree 2 underfits this data.

questions.question_text_1: You are given a linearly separable dataset with feature matrix X, for which a perceptron has been trained until it converges (perfectly separates the data). The weight vector corresponding to it is w. This dataset has 70 points from the positive class and 30 from the negative class. What is the output of the following snippet of code?

questions.question_text_1: A Gaussian Naive Bayes model is trained for a multi-class classification problem that has 10 features and 3 classes. Find the total number of parameters that have to be estimated for this model. Consider each parameter to be a scalar value. In other words, if we decide to store all the parameters in a Python list, with each element of the list being a float value corresponding to a single parameter, what is the size of this list? Ignore the priors in the calculation. Only focus on the parameters of the class conditional densities.
question_texts: A Gaussian Naive Bayes model is trained for a multi-class classification problem that has 10 features and 3 classes. Find the total number of parameters that have to be estimated for this model. Consider each parameter to be a scalar value. In other words, if we decide to store all the parameters in a Python list, with each element of the list being a float value corresponding to a single parameter, what is the size of this list? Ignore the priors in the calculation. Only focus on the parameters of the class conditional densities.

questions.question_text_1:
The MNIST digit classification problem has 10 classes. The training dataset has n data points, with an equal number of points from each of the 10 classes. Consider a dummy classifier that does prediction as follows: for each input data-point, it picks one of the 10 classes at random (uniformly) and outputs that as its prediction. What is the accuracy of the model on the training dataset as n
becomes very large? Your answer should be between 0 and 1. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.  Hint: Think about it in the probabilistic sense.
question_texts:
The MNIST digit classification problem has 10 classes. The training dataset has n data points, with an equal number of points from each of the 10 classes. Consider a dummy classifier that does prediction as follows: for each input data-point, it picks one of the 10 classes at random (uniformly) and outputs that as its prediction. What is the accuracy of the model on the training dataset as n
becomes very large? Your answer should be between 0 and 1. Enter your answer correct to two decimal places.  Hint: Think about it in the probabilistic sense.

cluster-2
can not be determined

questions.question_text_1: If Wij is the weight of the edge from neuron i in layer l − 1 to neuron j in layer l, which of the following statements about the matrix W are true? Neurons in a layer are processed (indexed) from top to bottom. So, the first neuron in a layer is the top-most neuron in that layer.
question_texts: If Wij is the weight of the edge from neuron i in layer l − 1 to neuron j in layer l, which of the following statements about the matrix W are true? Neurons in a layer are processed (indexed) from top to bottom. So, the first neuron in a layer is the top-most neuron in that layer.

options.option_text: The first row of the matrix corresponds to all outgoing connections from thefirst neuron in layer l − 1.
The first row of the matrix corresponds to all incoming connections to the firstneuron in layer l.
The last column of the matrix corresponds to all incoming connections to thelast neuron in layer l.
The last column of the matrix corresponds to all the outgoing connectionsfrom the last neuron in layer l − 1.

props.summary:
Here’s a structured **summary of core topics, concepts, principles, and equations** essential for the exam, followed by **Mermaid knowledge graphs** to visualize relationships.

---

## **Core Topics & Concepts**
### **1. Supervised Learning**
#### **A. Linear Models**
- **Perceptron Algorithm**:
  - Convergence is **independent of learning rate (α)** for linearly separable data (Q3).
  - Update rule: \( w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha \cdot y_i \cdot x_i \) (if misclassified).
  - Decision boundary: \( w^T x + b = 0 \).

- **Linear Regression**:
  - **Loss (MSE)**: \( L(w) = \frac{1}{n} \sum_{i=1}^n (y_i - w^T x_i)^2 \) (Q9, Q11, Q19).
  - **Gradient**: \( \nabla_w L(w) = \frac{2}{n} X^T (Xw - y) \).
  - **Ridge Regression (L2)**: \( L(w) = \text{MSE} + \lambda \|w\|_2^2 \) (Q19).
    - Gradient: \( \nabla_w L(w) = \frac{2}{n} X^T (Xw - y) + 2\lambda w \).

- **Logistic Regression**:
  - **Sigmoid**: \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \).
  - **Loss (Cross-Entropy)**: \( L(w) = -\sum_{i=1}^n [y_i \log(\hat{y}_i) + (1-y_i) \log(1-\hat{y}_i)] \).
  - **Decision Boundary**: \( w^T x + b = 0 \) (Q24, Q28).
  - **Threshold (T)**: \( \hat{y} = 1 \) if \( P(y=1|x) \geq T \), else \( 0 \).
    - If \( T = \frac{e}{1+e} \), then \( u = 1 \) (Q28).

#### **B. Non-Linear Models**
- **Polynomial Regression**:
  - Degree selection:
    - **Low degree (1-2)**: Underfitting (high bias) (Q17).
    - **High degree (e.g., 99)**: Overfitting (high variance) (Q17).
  - **Feature transformation**: \( \phi(x) = [1, x, x^2, ..., x^d] \).

- **Neural Networks**:
  - **Activation Functions**:
    - **ReLU**: \( \text{ReLU}(z) = \max(0, z) \).
    - **Sigmoid**: \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \).
    - **Tanh**: \( \tanh(z) = \frac{e^z - e^{-z}}{e^z + e^{-z}} \) (Q6).
    - **Softmax**: \( \text{softmax}(z)_i = \frac{e^{z_i}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \) (Q6, Q31).
  - **Architecture**:
    - **Parameters**: Weights (\( W \)) + biases (\( b \)).
      - For layer \( l \): \( W \in \mathbb{R}^{n_{l-1} \times n_l} \), \( b \in \mathbb{R}^{n_l} \).
      - Total parameters: \( \sum_{l=1}^L (n_{l-1} \cdot n_l + n_l) \) (Q22).
    - **Forward Pass**: \( z^{(l)} = W^{(l)} a^{(l-1)} + b^{(l)} \), \( a^{(l)} = \text{activation}(z^{(l)}) \).
  - **Training**:
    - **Backpropagation**: Chain rule for gradients.
    - **Weight Update**: \( W \leftarrow W - \alpha \nabla_W L \).

- **Support Vector Machines (SVM)**:
  - **Hinge Loss**: \( L(w) = \max(0, 1 - y_i (w^T x_i + b)) \) (Q30).
  - **Soft-Margin SVM**: \( \min_w \frac{1}{2} \|w\|_2^2 + C \sum \xi_i \) (Q30).
  - **Decision Boundary**: \( w^T x + b = 0 \).
  - **Probability Estimation**: For a random point in \([0,1]^2\) with \( w = [2, 1] \), \( b = -1 \), \( P(\hat{y} = +1) = 0.75 \) (Q29).

#### **C. Tree-Based Models**
- **Decision Trees**:
  - **Splitting Criteria**:
    - **Gini Index**: \( G = 1 - \sum p_i^2 \).
    - **Entropy**: \( H = -\sum p_i \log(p_i) \).
    - **Misclassification Error**: \( 1 - \max(p_i) \).
  - **Plot Analysis**: For binary classification, Gini and Entropy are symmetric around \( p_1 = 0.5 \), while misclassification error is linear (Q5).

- **Random Forest**:
  - **Feature Subsampling**: Decreasing \( p \) (features per split) reduces correlation between trees (Q8).
  - **Performance**: Increasing \( p \) improves individual tree performance but may increase correlation (Q8).

- **AdaBoost**:
  - **Stumps**: Weak learners (e.g., splits on \( X_1 \)).
  - **Sample Weights**: Updated based on misclassification (Q34, Q35).
  - **Gini Index**: Used for splits (Q34).

- **Regression Trees**:
  - **Prediction**: Average of samples in a leaf (Q32, Q33).

#### **D. Evaluation Metrics**
- **Confusion Matrix**:
  - **Precision**: \( \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \) (Q10).
  - **Recall**: \( \frac{TP}{TP + FN} \).
  - **F1-Score**: \( 2 \cdot \frac{\text{Precision} \cdot \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}} \).
  - **Trade-off**: If \( p_1 > p_2 \) and F1 is same, then \( r_1 < r_2 \) (Q14).

- **Accuracy**:
  - For a **dummy classifier** (uniform random guess), accuracy = \( \frac{1}{\text{num_classes}} \) (Q23).

### **2. Unsupervised Learning**
#### **A. Clustering**
- **K-Means**:
  - **Algorithm**:
    1. Initialize centroids.
    2. Assign points to nearest centroid (Manhattan/Euclidean distance).
    3. Update centroids as mean of assigned points.
  - **Silhouette Score (S)**:
    - \( S = \frac{b - a}{\max(a, b)} \), where:
      - \( a \): Mean intra-cluster distance.
      - \( b \): Mean nearest-cluster distance.
    - **Interpretation**:
      - \( S \approx 1 \): Well-separated clusters.
      - \( S \approx 0 \): Overlapping clusters.
      - \( S < 0 \): Incorrect clustering (Q12).

#### **B. Dimensionality Reduction**
- **PCA**: Not directly covered, but relevant for feature transformation.

### **3. Probabilistic Models**
- **Naive Bayes**:
  - **Gaussian Naive Bayes**:
    - Parameters: Mean (\( \mu \)) and variance (\( \sigma^2 \)) per feature per class.
    - **Total Parameters**: \( 2 \times \text{num_features} \times \text{num_classes} \) (Q21).
  - **Assumption**: Features are conditionally independent given the class.

### **4. Optimization**
- **Gradient Descent**:
  - **Update Rule**: \( w \leftarrow w - \alpha \nabla_w L(w) \).
  - **Learning Rate (\( \alpha \))**: Affects convergence speed but not final solution for convex problems (Q3).
- **Stochastic Gradient Descent (SGD)**: Mini-batch updates for efficiency.

### **5. Model Selection & Evaluation**
- **Bias-Variance Tradeoff**:
  - **Underfitting**: High bias (e.g., linear model on non-linear data).
  - **Overfitting**: High variance (e.g., high-degree polynomial).
- **Cross-Validation**: Train/validation/test splits to evaluate generalization.
- **k-NN**:
  - **Hyperparameter (k)**: Larger \( k \) reduces noise but may underfit (Q4).
    - If \( k=10 \) has low training error but high validation error, increase \( k \) to smooth decision boundaries.

### **6. Multi-Label vs. Multi-Class**
- **Multi-Class**: Single label per sample (e.g., digit classification).
- **Multi-Label**: Multiple labels per sample (e.g., predicting goals in 10 matches) (Q7).

### **7. Python & NumPy**
- **Array Operations**:
  - `np.arange`, `np.linspace`, `np.ones`, `np.random.rand` (Q15, Q18).
  - Reshaping: `reshape(-1)` flattens an array (Q15).
- **Broadcasting**: Element-wise operations on arrays of different shapes.

---

## **Key Equations**
| **Topic**               | **Equation**                                                                 |
|-------------------------|-----------------------------------------------------------------------------|
| **Perceptron Update**   | \( w_{t+1} = w_t + \alpha \cdot y_i \cdot x_i \) (if misclassified)         |
| **Linear Regression**   | \( L(w) = \frac{1}{n} \sum (y_i - w^T x_i)^2 \)                             |
| **Ridge Regression**    | \( L(w) = \text{MSE} + \lambda \|w\|_2^2 \)                                |
| **Logistic Regression** | \( P(y=1|x) = \sigma(w^T x) \), \( \sigma(z) = \frac{1}{1 + e^{-z}} \)      |
| **SVM Hinge Loss**      | \( L(w) = \max(0, 1 - y_i (w^T x_i + b)) \)                                |
| **Softmax**             | \( \text{softmax}(z)_i = \frac{e^{z_i}}{\sum_j e^{z_j}} \)                 |
| **Gini Index**          | \( G = 1 - \sum p_i^2 \)                                                    |
| **Entropy**             | \( H = -\sum p_i \log(p_i) \)                                               |
| **Silhouette Score**    | \( S = \frac{b - a}{\max(a, b)} \)                                          |
| **Precision**           | \( \text{Precision} = \frac{TP}{TP + FP} \)                                |
| **F1-Score**            | \( F1 = 2 \cdot \frac{\text{Precision} \cdot \text{Recall}}{\text{Precision} + \text{Recall}} \) |
| **Gradient of MSE**     | \( \nabla_w L(w) = \frac{2}{n} X^T (Xw - y) \)                             |
| **Gradient of Weighted MSE** | \( \nabla_w L(w) = \sum r_i (w^T x_i - y_i) x_i \) (Q11)               |

---

## **Mermaid Knowledge Graphs**
### **1. Supervised Learning Hierarchy**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Supervised Learning] --> B[Regression]
    A --> C[Classification]
    B --> D[Linear Regression]
    B --> E[Polynomial Regression]
    B --> F[Ridge/Lasso]
    C --> G[Logistic Regression]
    C --> H[SVM]
    C --> I[Decision Trees]
    C --> J[Neural Networks]
    I --> K[Random Forest]
    I --> L[AdaBoost]
    J --> M[MLP]
    J --> N[CNN]
```

### **2. Model Evaluation Metrics**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Evaluation Metrics] --> B[Classification]
    A --> C[Regression]
    B --> D[Confusion Matrix]
    D --> E[Precision]
    D --> F[Recall]
    D --> G[F1-Score]
    D --> H[Accuracy]
    C --> I[MSE]
    C --> J[R²]
```

### **3. Neural Network Architecture**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Input Layer] -->|Weights| B[Hidden Layer 1]
    B -->|Activation| C[Hidden Layer 2]
    C -->|Weights| D[Output Layer]
    D --> E[Softmax/Sigmoid]
```

### **4. Clustering Algorithms**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Clustering] --> B[K-Means]
    A --> C[Hierarchical]
    A --> D[DBSCAN]
    B --> E[Centroids]
    B --> F[Silhouette Score]
    F --> G[Interpretation]
```

### **5. Bias-Variance Tradeoff**
```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Model Complexity] -->|Low| B[High Bias/Underfitting]
    A -->|High| C[High Variance/Overfitting]
    B --> D[Train Error ≈ Test Error]
    C --> E[Train Error << Test Error]
```

### **6. Optimization Algorithms**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Optimization] --> B[Gradient Descent]
    A --> C[Stochastic GD]
    A --> D[Adam]
    B --> E[Batch Update]
    C --> F[Mini-Batch Update]
```

### **7. Probabilistic Models**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Probabilistic Models] --> B[Naive Bayes]
    A --> C[Bayesian Networks]
    B --> D[Gaussian NB]
    B --> E[Multinomial NB]
    D --> F[Mean/Variance per Class]
```

### **8. Tree-Based Models**
```mermaid
graph TD
    A[Tree-Based Models] --> B[Decision Trees]
    A --> C[Random Forest]
    A --> D[Gradient Boosting]
    B --> E[Gini/Entropy]
    C --> F[Feature Subsampling]
    D --> G[Sequential Correction]
```
